Nice paper, I enjoyed reading it; evolving networks that self-organise is a=

topic I'm very interested in!

I have a question about the unseeded treatm=
ent: did you try longer
evolutionary runs to see if it would eventually fin=
d a solution?
On 29/04/2014 2:19 AM, "Sebastian Risi" <sebastian.risi@gmail=
.com> wrote:

>
>
> Thanks Jeff! And congrats to you as well! Looks like yo=
ur group will be
> well represented at GECCO :)
>
>
> On Mon, Apr 28, 2014 =
at 6:14 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Congrats on the=
 paper! It looks fascinating. I look forward to reading it
>> soon.
>>
>>
>=
> Best regards,
>> *Jeff Clune*
>>
>> Assistant Professor
>> Computer Scien=
ce
>> University of Wyoming
>> jeffclune@...
>> jeffclune.com
>>
>> On=
 Apr 28, 2014, at 3:47 AM, Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@...>
>> wro=
te:
>>
>>
>>
>> Kenneth Stanley and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO=
 paper (to
>> appear), "Guided Self-Organization in Indirectly Encoded and =
Evolving
>> Topographic Maps"
>>
>> *PDF: *http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/r=
isi_gecco14.pdf
>>
>> This paper introduces the idea that HyperNEAT can be =
seeded with a
>> lateral inhibitory connectivity pattern, which then allows=
 the weights from
>> the inputs to the hidden layer of an ANN to self-organ=
ize to form a genuine
>> topographic map of the input space. The benefit of=
 this new approach is
>> that the initial seed can be evolved further to ac=
celerate the
>> self-organizing process and to bias it towards a specific t=
arget
>> configuration. An interesting implication is that enabling HyperNE=
AT to
>> capture this key feature of natural systems might now allow us to =
evolve
>> architectures resembling deep learning networks, SOMs, or other
>=
> self-organizing processes that also rely on unsupervised learning process=
es.
>>
>> *Abstract: *An important phenomenon seen in many areas of biologi=
cal
>> brains and recently in deep learning architectures is a process know=
n as
>> self-organization. For example, in the primary visual cortex, color=
 and
>> orientation maps develop based on lateral inhibitory connectivity p=
atterns
>> and Hebbian learning dynamics. These topographic maps, which are=
 found in
>> all sensory systems, are thought to be a key factor in enablin=
g abstract
>> cognitive representations. This paper shows for the first tim=
e that the
>> Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (Hype=
rNEAT) method
>> can be seeded to begin evolution  with such lateral connec=
tivity, enabling
>> genuine self-organizing dynamics. The proposed approach=
 draws on
>> HyperNEAT's ability to generate a pattern of weights across th=
e
>> connectivity of an artificial neural network (ANN) based on a function=
 of
>> its geometry. Validating this approach, the afferent weights of an A=
NN
>> self-organize in this paper to form a genuine topographic map of the =
input
>> space for a simple line orientation task. Most interestingly, this=
 seed can
>> then be evolved further, providing a method to guide the self-=
organization
>> of weights in a specific way, much as evolution likely guid=
ed the
>> self-organizing trajectories of biological brains.
>>
>> Cheers,
=
>> Sebastian
>>
>> --
>> Dr. Sebastian Risi
>> Assistant Professor
>> IT Un=
iversity of Copenhagen, Room 5D08
>> Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen=
, Denmark
>> email: sebastian.risi@..., web: www.sebastianrisi.com
>>=
 mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
>>
>>
>>

<p dir=3D"ltr">Nice paper, I enjoyed reading it; evolving networks that sel=
f-organise is a topic I'm very interested in! </p>
<p dir=3D"ltr">I hav=
e a question about the unseeded treatment: did you try longer evolutionary =
runs to see if it would eventually find a solution?</p>

<br><div><div>On Apr 28, 2014, at 3:47 AM, Sebastian Risi <=
<a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." target=3D"_blank">sebastian.ris=
i@...</a>> wrote:</div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite">












=
 
<div>
<span>=C2=A0</span>



    <div><div><br></div><div dir=3D"ltr">Ken=
neth Stanley and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO paper (to appear),=
 "Guided Self-Organization in Indirectly Encoded and Evolving Topograp=
hic Maps"<br><br><b>PDF: </b><a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers=
/risi_gecco14.pdf" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_ge=
cco14.pdf</a><br>


<br>This paper introduces the idea that HyperNEAT can b=
e seeded with a lateral inhibitory connectivity pattern, which then allows =
the weights from the inputs to the hidden layer=C2=A0of an ANN to self-orga=
nize to form a genuine topographic map of the input=C2=A0space. The benefit=
 of this new approach is that the initial seed can=C2=A0be evolved further =
to accelerate the self-organizing process and to=C2=A0bias it towards a spe=
cific target configuration. An interesting implication=C2=A0is that enablin=
g HyperNEAT to capture this key feature of=C2=A0natural systems might now a=
llow us to evolve architectures resembling=C2=A0deep learning networks, SOM=
s, or other self-organizing processes that also rely on unsupervised learni=
ng processes.<br>


<br><b>Abstract: </b>An important phenomenon seen in ma=
ny areas of biological brains and recently in deep learning architectures i=
s a process known as self-organization. For example, in the primary visual =
cortex, color and orientation maps develop based on lateral inhibitory conn=
ectivity patterns and Hebbian learning dynamics. These topographic maps, wh=
ich are found in all sensory systems, are thought to be a key factor in ena=
bling abstract cognitive representations. This paper shows for the first ti=
me that the Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (HyperN=
EAT) method can be seeded to begin evolution =C2=A0with such lateral connec=
tivity, enabling genuine self-organizing dynamics. The proposed approach dr=
aws on HyperNEAT's ability to generate a pattern of weights across the =
connectivity of an artificial neural network (ANN) based on a function of i=
ts geometry. Validating this approach, the afferent weights of an ANN self-=
organize in this paper to form a genuine topographic map of the input space=
 for a simple line orientation task. Most interestingly, this seed can then=
 be evolved further, providing a method to guide the self-organization of w=
eights in a specific way, much as evolution likely guided the self-organizi=
ng trajectories of biological brains.<br>


<br>Cheers,<br>Sebastian<br><br=
>--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Professor <br>IT University of Copen=
hagen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark<br>emai=
l: <a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." target=3D"_blank">sebastian.=
risi@...</a>, web: <a href=3D"http://www.sebastianrisi.com/" target=
